transcripts.text: welcome to this segment of our study of the bill of rights the fifth and sixth amendments.  the fifth amendment is the longest which reads no person shall be held to answer for a capital or other infamous crime unless on a presentment or indictment of a grand jury except in cases arising in the land or naval forces or in the militia when in actual service in time of war or public danger.  nor shall any person be subject for the same offense to be twice put in jeopardy of life and limb, nor should be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself, nor be deprived of life, liberty, or property without the due process of law, nor shall private property be taken for public use without just compensation.  When you look at this amendment through the Eighth Amendment, they are interrelated, but since the subject is so long and intricate as they pertain to general jurisprudence, they split them up.  The Fifth Amendment says that except when one serves in a military capacity in the Army or Navy, or the militia when actually on duty, no person can be held for a crime unless a warrant is issued as a result of a grand jury decision.  Now the military is different, and it comes under something called the Uniform Code of Military Justice, because the military services need to have control over the services, and this cannot be done unless they have their own system of justice. The best-known aspect of the Fifth Amendment is the fact that a person cannot be compelled to testify against himself without reprisal. In other words, the Fifth Amendment sets the stage for the Sixth Amendment, which reads, In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy and public trial by an impartial jury of the state and district wherein the crime shall have been committed, which district shall have been previously ascertained by law and to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation, to be confronted with witnesses against him, to have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his favor, and to have the assistance of counsel for his defense.  So we see that a person has a right to a speedy trial.  This provision has been eroded considerably over the years.  It can take years before a trial will commence.  today.
